Question.content:
Circle the secondary amine(s) from the compound below:
(i) \(CH_3N(CH_3)_2\)
(ii) \(CH_3CH_2NHCH_3\)
(iii) \((CH_3)_2CHNH_2\)
(iv) \(CH_3NHCH_2CH_3\)

Explanation.content:
A secondary amine has two carbon groups attached to the nitrogen (N).

Breakdown:
- (i) \(CH_3N(CH_3)_2\): Tertiary (3 carbons on N).
- (ii) \(CH_3CH_2NHCH_3\): Secondary (2 carbons: \(CH_3CH_2\)- and \(CH_3\) ).
- (iii) \((CH_3)_2CHNH_2\): Primary (1 carbon on N).
- (iv) \(CH_3NHCH_2CH_3\): Secondary 2.) carbons: \(CH_3\)- and \(CH_2CH_3\).

Why? Only (ii) and (iv) fit the rule!

Question.content: Provide a correct systemic name for 2-chloro-2-bromo-3-hydroxyl pentane

Explanation.content:
• The hydroxy group (OH) is named as 'ol' suffix in IUPAC nomenclature
  • Halogens (Br, Cl) are named as prefixes in alphabetical order
  • The parent chain is pentane (5 carbons)
  • The correct numbering gives the hydroxyl group priority at position 3

Question.content: Identify the class of the organic compound; \(CH_3CO_2COCH_3\)

Answer.content: Acid anhydride (general formula \(RCOOCOR\) where R = alkyl group)

Explanation.content:
• The compound has two acyl groups (\(RCO-\)) bonded to the same oxygen
  • This \(-CO-O-CO-\) structure is characteristic of acid anhydrides
  • Formed by condensation of two carboxylic acids
  • Named by replacing 'acid' with 'anhydride' in the parent acid names

Question.content: Arrange n-hexane, cyclohexane and 3-methyl pentane in an order of decreasing boiling point

Explanation.content:
• Cyclohexane has the highest boiling point due to its rigid cyclic structure allowing closer molecular packing
  • n-Hexane (straight chain) has stronger London dispersion forces than branched 3-methylpentane
  • 3-Methylpentane has the lowest boiling point because branching reduces surface area and intermolecular forces

Question.content: What is the product of the reaction of hydrogen bromide with propene?

Explanation.content:
• Follows Markovnikov's rule: H adds to the less substituted carbon
  • Br adds to the more substituted carbon (C2) forming 2-bromopropane
  • The reaction mechanism involves formation of a more stable secondary carbocation intermediate

Question.content: Account for the difference in boiling points between methoxymethane and ethanol, although both have the same molecular formula

Answer.content: Ethanol can form hydrogen bonding whereas methoxymethane cannot.

Explanation.content:
• Ethanol (CH3CH2OH): Forms strong intermolecular hydrogen bonds (O-H⋯O) requiring more energy to break
  • Methoxymethane (CH3OCH3): Only has weaker dipole-dipole interactions (no H-bonding)
  • Hydrogen bonding increases ethanol's boiling point by ≈20°C compared to methoxymethane

Question.content: Draw the structure of the product of reaction of benzene with ethanoyl chloride in the presence of \(AlCl_3\)

Explanation.content:
• This is a Friedel-Crafts acylation reaction
  • \(AlCl_3\) acts as a Lewis acid catalyst
  • The product is phenylethanone (acetophenone) - a benzene ring with \(COCH_3\) group
  • Mechanism involves formation of acylium ion (\(RCO^+\)) electrophile

Question.content: List any two modern techniques for structural elucidation of organic compounds

Explanation.content:
• NMR: Provides information about carbon-hydrogen framework (chemical environment of nuclei)
  • IR Spectroscopy: Identifies functional groups through characteristic vibrational frequencies
  • Other important techniques include Mass Spectrometry and X-ray Crystallography

Question.content: Name any two techniques used for separation of a mixture of organic compounds

Explanation.content:
• Chromatography: Separates components based on differential partitioning between mobile and stationary phases (HPLC, GC, TLC)
  • Distillation: Separates based on differences in boiling points (simple, fractional, vacuum)
  • Other methods include extraction, crystallization, and sublimation

Question.content: What type of isomerism exists in 2-chloropentane and 3-chloropentane

Explanation.content:
• Positional isomers have the same molecular formula but differ in the position of functional groups
  • Both compounds are C5H11Cl with chlorine at different carbon positions (C-2 vs C-3)
  • They have different physical properties and slightly different chemical reactivity

Question.content: Provide a structure for the compound ethyl methanoate

Explanation.content:
• Ethyl methanoate is an ester with formula HCOOCH2CH3
  • Formed from methanoic acid (HCOOH) and ethanol (CH3CH2OH)
  • Contains ester functional group (-COO-) between formyl and ethyl groups
  • Characteristic fruity smell common to simple esters

Question.content: A mixture of hexane and water is said to be

Explanation.content:
• Immiscible liquids don't mix to form a homogeneous solution
  • Hexane (nonpolar) and water (polar) have different intermolecular forces
  • Water forms hydrogen bonds while hexane only has London dispersion forces
  • They separate into distinct layers with hexane floating on water (density 0.66 g/mL vs 1.0 g/mL)

Question.content: What is the relationship between bond length and unsaturation?

Answer.content: Bond length decreases with increase in unsaturation (sp³ > sp² > sp)

Explanation.content:
• sp³ hybridized (single bonds): Longest bond length (e.g., C-C 1.54Å)
  • sp² hybridized (double bonds): Shorter (e.g., C=C 1.34Å) due to increased s-character
  • sp hybridized (triple bonds): Shortest (e.g., C≡C 1.20Å) with 50% s-character
  • Higher s-character means electrons are held closer to nucleus, shortening bond length

Question.content: An organic compound has an empirical formula of CH₂O and a molecular weight of 60. Give the molecular formula of the compound

Explanation.content:
• Empirical formula weight = 12 (C) + 2×1 (H) + 16 (O) = 30 g/mol
  • Molecular weight = 60 g/mol
  • Multiplier = 60/30 = 2
  • Molecular formula = 2×(CH₂O) = \(C_2H_4O_2\) (e.g., acetic acid)

Question.content: Which of these are chromatographic techniques in the study of organic compounds? (i) Thin layer (ii) Carbon (iii) Paper (iv) Gas (v) Solid

Explanation.content:
• Thin Layer Chromatography (TLC): Uses silica gel plate and solvent
  • Paper Chromatography: Uses cellulose paper as stationary phase
  • Gas Chromatography (GC): Uses inert gas mobile phase
  • Carbon and Solid are not chromatographic techniques (they may be stationary phases)

Question.content: What does the homolysis of bonds yield?

Explanation.content:
• Homolytic cleavage: Bond breaks evenly, with one electron going to each atom
  • Forms highly reactive radicals (species with unpaired electrons)
  • Requires energy input (heat/light)
  • Important in radical chain reactions (e.g., halogenation of alkanes)
  • Contrast with heterolysis which forms ions

Question.content: What types of hybrid orbitals are responsible for the bonds found in propyne?

Explanation.content:
• Propyne (CH≡C-CH₃) contains two types of bonds:
  • sp hybridized carbons in C≡C triple bond (linear 180° geometry)
  • sp³ hybridized carbon in terminal CH₃ group (tetrahedral 109.5° geometry)
  • The central carbon forms both sp-sp (C≡C) and sp-sp³ (C-CH₃) sigma bonds

Question.content: What are the reagents required to produce 1-bromo-1-methylcyclopentane from 1-methylcyclopentene?

Explanation.content:
• This is an electrophilic addition reaction following Markovnikov's rule
  • HBr adds across the double bond of 1-methylcyclopentene
  • The bromine attaches to the more substituted carbon (position 1)
  • Forms 1-bromo-1-methylcyclopentane as the major product
  • No peroxide effect needed for this anti-Markovnikov product

Question.content: What is the IUPAC nomenclature of the compound \(CH_3CH_2OCH_3\)?

Explanation.content:
• This is an ether with formula C₂H₅OCH₃
  • IUPAC naming: alkoxy + alkane
  • Identify the shorter alkyl group (methoxy, -OCH₃) as prefix
  • Longer carbon chain (ethane, C₂H₅) as parent name
  • Common name: Ethyl methyl ether

Question.content: What differentiates a class of organic compound from another?

Explanation.content:
• Functional groups determine chemical properties and reactivity
  • Examples: -OH (alcohols), -COOH (carboxylic acids), C=O (carbonyls)
  • Same carbon skeleton with different functional groups = different classes
  • Functional groups are the basis of organic compound classification
  • They dictate physical properties (bp/mp/solubility) and reaction types

Question.content: Write an equation that describes the complete combustion of butane

Explanation.content:
• Complete combustion converts hydrocarbons to CO₂ and H₂O
  • Butane (\(C_4H_{10}\)) reacts with oxygen
  • Balanced equation shows 2:13:8:10 mole ratio
  • Alternative form: \(C_4H_{10} + 6.5O_2 \rightarrow 4CO_2 + 5H_2O\)
  • Exothermic reaction releasing ~2877 kJ/mol

Question.content: Give the structures or names of the reagents that will be required to produce ethylbenzene from benzene

Explanation.content:
• This is a Friedel-Crafts alkylation reaction
  • Chloroethane (ethyl chloride) provides ethyl group
  • AlCl₃ acts as Lewis acid catalyst
  • Mechanism forms electrophilic carbocation (\(CH_3CH_2^+\))
  • Product is ethylbenzene (\(C_6H_5CH_2CH_3\))

Question.content: Draw the structure of the main product of treating cyclopentene with cold \(KMnO_4\)

Explanation.content:
• Cold, dilute \(KMnO_4\) performs syn-hydroxylation
  • Converts alkene to vicinal diol (1,2-diol)
  • Forms cis-1,2-cyclopentanediol (OH groups on same side)
  • Purple \(KMnO_4\) decolorizes during reaction
  • Contrast with hot \(KMnO_4\) which cleaves the ring

Question.content: What is the general formula for cycloalkanes?

Explanation.content:
• Cycloalkanes have two fewer hydrogens than alkanes (\(C_nH_{2n+2}\))
  • Each ring reduces hydrogen count by 2 (one pair per C-C bond formed)
  • Examples: Cyclopropane (\(C_3H_6\)), cyclohexane (\(C_6H_{12}\))
  • Same formula as alkenes but different functional groups

Question.content: What is the product of treating 1-butyne with 1 mole of chlorine

Explanation.content:
• 1-butyne (\(CH≡CCH_2CH_3\)) undergoes electrophilic addition with Cl₂
  • First Cl adds to terminal alkyne carbon, forming chloronium ion intermediate
  • Second Cl adds anti to first, creating trans-dichloro product
  • Product is 1,2-dichloro-1-butene (not 2-ene as originally stated)
  • Markovnikov orientation observed

Question.content: In a laboratory set up for paper chromatography, the distance travelled by a substance is 3cm calculate the Rf value if the distance travelled by the solvent is 4.5cm

Explanation.content:
• Retention factor (Rf) = Distance traveled by compound ÷ Distance traveled by solvent
  • Calculation: \(R_f = 3cm ÷ 4.5cm = 0.666...\)
  • Rounded to 2 significant figures: 0.67
  • Rf values range 0-1 and are characteristic for compounds under specific conditions

Question.content: The ability of carbon to form chains with itself is called

Explanation.content:
• Catenation: Unique property of carbon to form long chains/rings
  • Results from carbon's tetravalency and strong C-C bonds (348 kJ/mol)
  • Enables formation of complex organic molecules
  • Other elements (Si, S) show limited catenation
  • Basis for structural diversity in organic chemistry

Question.content: State as true or false the statement that all organic compounds contain carbon and hydrogen only.

Explanation.content:
• Organic compounds must contain carbon but may include other elements
  • Common examples with other elements: Alcohols (-OH), amines (-NH₂), carboxylic acids (-COOH)
  • Some contain halogens (CFCs), oxygen (CO₂), nitrogen (proteins), etc.
  • Exception: Carbon oxides, carbides, carbonates are usually considered inorganic

Question.content: Give the full meaning of NMR

Explanation.content:
• NMR spectroscopy analyzes nuclear spin transitions in magnetic fields
  • Key structural tool in organic chemistry (¹H NMR, ¹³C NMR)
  • Provides information about:
    • Molecular structure
    • Atomic environment
    • Bond connectivity
    • Molecular dynamics
  • Works by measuring absorption of radio waves by nuclei

Question.content: The positively charged species in heterolytic cleavage is called

Explanation.content:
• Heterolytic cleavage produces charged fragments
  • The carbocation is the electron-deficient species (R+)
  • Stability order: 3° > 2° > 1° > methyl
  • Key intermediates in SN1 reactions and electrophilic additions

Question.content: An electrophile is a reagent that attacks a substrate at a position of low electron density

Explanation.content:
• Electrophiles attack high electron density sites (π bonds/lone pairs)
  • They are electron-seeking species (Lewis acids)
  • Common electrophiles: H+, Br+, NO2+, carbocations
  • The statement describes a nucleophile's behavior

Question.content: Draw the structure and give the IUPAC name of an alkane with the molecular formula \(C_5H_{12}\) that has only primary hydrogens

Explanation.content:
• Only 2,2-dimethylpropane (neopentane) satisfies this condition
  • Central quaternary carbon with four methyl groups
  • All 12 hydrogens are equivalent and primary
  • No secondary or tertiary hydrogens present

Question.content: Give the name and structure of the product of hydrobromination of propene

Explanation.content:
• Follows Markovnikov's rule: H adds to less substituted carbon
  • Br adds to C-2 forming 2-bromopropane
  • Mechanism proceeds through more stable secondary carbocation
  • Anti-Markovnikov product forms only with peroxide (HBr/ROOR)

Question.content: In a chromatographic separation technique, Rf means

Explanation.content:
• Rf = Distance traveled by spot ÷ Distance traveled by solvent front
  • Dimensionless value between 0-1
  • Used to identify compounds by comparison with standards
  • Depends on compound's affinity for stationary vs mobile phase

Question.content: Which of the following is NOT a carboxylic acid derivative? \((i) CH_3CO_2H\) \((ii) CH_3CONH_2\) \((iii) CH_3CH_2CH_2Cl\) \((iv) CH_3CH_2COCl\)

Explanation.content:
• Carboxylic acid derivatives contain acyl group (R-CO-)
  • (i) Acetic acid (parent acid)
  • (ii) Acetamide (amide derivative)
  • (iv) Propanoyl chloride (acid chloride)
  • (iii) Propyl chloride is a simple alkyl halide, not acyl derivative
